bestBHT.bht: In a beautiful act of devotion, Mary of Bethany anointed the feet of Jesus with a pound of precious spikenard. This fragrant perfume was a costly offering, poured out to refresh and honor Jesus. As the fragrance of the ointment filled the house, Mary's love and gratitude were poured out for all to see. Her disregard for social norms, in letting her hair down, showed that her love for Christ surpassed any concerns of propriety. This act of anointing symbolized the sweet savour of Christ's ministry, spreading throughout the world.

Henry Alford: 3.] On spike-nard, see note on Mark. anointed the feet of Jesus] His head, according to Matthew and Mark. See note on Luke vii. 38.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The only use of this was to refresh and exhilarate—a grateful compliment in the East, amidst the closeness of a heated atmosphere, with many guests at a feast."
Such was the form in which Mary's love to Christ, at so much cost to herself, poured itself out.
Marvin Vincent: A pound. Only here and John 19:39. Matthew and Mark, ajlabastron, a flask.
Of spikenard. So Mark. See on Mark 14:3.
Very precious. Literally, of much value. Matthew has barutimou, of weighty value.
John Calvin: And the house was filled with the odor of the ointment.
It was not a simple liquor extracted from spikenard, but a compound of many odoriferous substances.
Therefore it is not wonderful that the whole house was filled with the odor.
Philip Schaff: The most probable opinion is that pistic is a geographical term which was at the time familiarly associated with the name of the perfume as an article of commerce, though now the exact significance is lost.
With this precious perfume, then, Mary anointed the feet of her Lord.
Mary’s action as here described, her use of the most precious ointment, whose odour filled the whole house [...] picture to us most impressively her gratitude and humble reverence.
Archibald T. Robertson: Nard is the head or spike of an East Indian plant, very fragrant."
πολυτιμου (very precious), Old compound adjective, in N.T. only here."

It is no doubt true that it was usually considered immodest for a woman to wear her hair loose. But it is not impossible that Mary of Bethany in her carefully planned love-offering for Jesus on this occasion was only glad to throw such a punctilio to the winds.
John Gill: Then took Mary a pound of ointment of spikenard very costly....worth three hundred pence..."
And wiped his feet with her hair...
This may be an emblem of the sweet savour of Christ, in the ministration of the Gospel, throughout the whole world.
John Wesley: There were two persons who poured ointment on Christ.
One toward the beginning of his ministry... The other six days before his last passover.
The account of whom is given here, as well as by St. Matthew and Mark.

bhtAttempts.bht: In a beautiful act of devotion, Mary of Bethany anointed the feet of Jesus with a pound of precious spikenard. This fragrant perfume was a costly offering, poured out to refresh and honor Jesus. As the fragrance of the ointment filled the house, Mary's love and gratitude were poured out for all to see. Her disregard for social norms, in letting her hair down, showed that her love for Christ surpassed any concerns of propriety. This act of anointing symbolized the sweet savour of Christ's ministry, spreading throughout the world and impacting all who encountered it. Truly, Mary's love and devotion continue to inspire us today.

In a beautiful act of devotion, Mary of Bethany anointed the feet of Jesus with a pound of precious spikenard. This fragrant perfume was a costly offering, poured out to refresh and honor Jesus. As the fragrance of the ointment filled the house, Mary's love and gratitude were poured out for all to see. Her disregard for social norms, in letting her hair down, showed that her love for Christ surpassed any concerns of propriety. This act of anointing symbolized the sweet savour of Christ's ministry, spreading throughout the world.

Mary of Bethany displayed an extraordinary act of devotion by anointing Jesus' feet with a pound of precious spikenard. The fragrance filled the house, signifying the poured out love and gratitude she had for Him. Mary's gesture went beyond societal expectations, demonstrating that her love for Christ surpassed propriety. This anointing was a symbol of the fragrant influence of Christ's ministry, spreading throughout the world. Her act continues to inspire us as a testament to the depth of love we can offer to our Savior.

In a remarkable act of devotion, Mary of Bethany anointed the feet of Jesus with a pound of precious spikenard, a costly perfume. The wonderful fragrance permeated the entire house, representing the outpouring of love and gratitude from Mary's heart. Her willingness to disregard social norms, by letting her hair down, revealed her deep love for Christ. This anointing symbolized the sweet aroma of Christ's ministry, spreading throughout the world. Mary's act of devotion continues to inspire us to offer our heartfelt love to our Savior.

Mary of Bethany demonstrated an extraordinary act of devotion by anointing the feet of Jesus with a pound of precious spikenard. The fragrance filled the house and served as a symbolic expression of Mary's poured-out love and gratitude. In her act of anointing, Mary disregarded societal conventions, allowing her hair to flow freely, revealing her deep affection for Christ. This act of anointing represented the sweet aroma of Christ's ministry, permeating the world. Mary's devoted act serves as an inspiration for us to offer our unwavering love and devotion to our Savior.
